_prev_prog_3.MD_OtherType: Engine room is equipped with ammonia detectors
_prev_prog_3.CH_OtherChanges: This is a new facility. Only an initial PHA has been conducted (it was completed on March 18, 2008).

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Capital Wholesale Meats uses a direct ammonia refrigeration system for cooling Process Rooms, Holding Freezers, Coolers, Docks and Blast Freezers.  The refrigeration system uses ammonia refrigerant in a two stage evaporation/condensation cycle.

The ammonia related equipment could be divided into three sections.  
1.	The ¿low pressure¿ equipment contains (3) Freezer Evaporators, (2) Blast Cells, (4) Spiral Freezers, (1) Low Temp Pump Package (LTPR), (1) Oil Pot and (2) Booster Compressors.    
2.	The ¿intermediate pressure¿ equipment contains (2) Blast Chillers, (1) Corridor Evaporator, (10) Process Room Evaporators, (3) Dock Evaporators, (5) Roof Top Units, (1) Water Chiller, (1) Gravy Chiller, (1) High Temp Pump Package (HTPR), (1) Oil Pot, (1) Swing Compressor, and (3) High Stage Compressors.
3.	The ¿high-pressure¿ equipment includes the (2) Evaporative Condensers and (1) High Pressure Receiver (HPR) and associated piping/valves.

Ammonia refrigeration provides cooling by utilizing the heat input required to change a liquid to a vapor (latent heat of evaporation) and then heat output discharged when a gas collapses to form liquid (latent heat of condensation). `Heat¿ is quantified by definition and is `labeled¿ as calories or Btu (British Thermal Unit).  One Btu, by definition, equals the amount of heat required to raise the temperature of one pound of water, 1 ºF when the water is 70 ºF, and at sea level pressure.  All other compounds reference this definition.  For example, the amount of heat required to raise the temperature of liquid ammonia at 70 ºF and 128.8 psia  = 1.129 Btu/lb (this is also referred to as the ¿Specific Heat¿). The amount of heat required to vaporize 1 pound of ammonia (at a corresponding pressure to 70 ºF, 128.8 psia) = 508.6 Btu.  Therefore, a system is 500 times more efficient in heat transfer per pound of ammonia utilized if the system incorporates change of state: liquid boiling off forming a vapor.

This `heat¿ must be removed from t

he system or the system would reach a point that no more `heat¿ could be absorbed (e.g. the liquid evaporates, and now must be condensed).  This is accomplished by compressing the gas to a pressure such that Air/Water passing over the Condenser coils would accept heat from the gas.  The (vaporized) gas, in rejecting heat, condenses, and thus provides liquid to begin the cycle again.

The ammonia flow direction is based on pressure differences (either by gravity or forced) and by the difference in volume between a gas and a liquid containing the same amount of ammonia.  The active driver of this system is the compressor.

The evaporation/condensation cycle is as follows:
Low Pressure Suction
	Ammonia liquid is pumped from the Low Temp Pump Package (LTPR) to the low-temp evaporators where heat is absorbed from the rooms.  The liquid ammonia boils absorbing the room heat and is converted from a liquid to a vapor.  Not all of the liquid boils off.  The mixture of liquid and vapor then returns to the Low Temp Pump Package (LTPR) where the liquid and vapor are separated so that the liquid can be circulated back to the evaporators.

	The low-pressure vapor passes through the Low Temp Pump Package (LTPR) and enters the Booster Compressor suction line.  In the Booster Compressor, the vapor is compressed to a higher pressure.  In this case it is compressed to 33.4 PSIG.  The ammonia is co-mingled with lubricating oil in the compressor.

	The ammonia vapor is directed to the oil separator to remove the majority of oil (employed to lubricate and cool the compressor) before being discharged to the Intercooler/High Temp Pump Package (HTPR) and then to the High Stage Compressors.

	Liquid from the High Temp Pump Package (HTPR) is then fed to the Low Temp Pump Package (LTPR) to replace the liquid that was boiled out of the low temperature system.

Intermediate Suction
	Ammonia liquid is pumped from the High Temp Pump Package (HTPR) to the intermediate-temp evaporators where heat is

absorbed from the rooms.  The liquid ammonia boils absorbing the room heat and is converted from a liquid to a vapor.  Not all of the liquid boils off.  The mixture of liquid and vapor then returns to the High Temp Pump Package (HTPR) where the liquid and vapor are separated so that the liquid can be circulated back to the evaporators.

	The ammonia vapor from the high temp loads and booster compressors, at intermediate pressure, pass through the High Temp Pump Package (HTPR) and enters the High Stage Compressor suction line.  In the High Stage Compressor, the vapor is compressed to superheated, higher pressure.  The ammonia is co-mingled with lubricating oil in the compressor.

	The ammonia vapor is directed to the oil separator to remove the majority of oil (employed to lubricate and cool the compressor) before being discharged to the evaporative condensers as superheated, high-pressure vapor.

Condensing
	The high-pressure vapor passes to the evaporative condensers where the heat is rejected from the gaseous ammonia to the atmosphere and the ammonia is condensed into liquid. The fans and water pumps automatically start (sequentially) to maintain the ammonia high-pressure set point.

	The condensed liquid ammonia is collected in the High Pressure Receiver (HPR) and then is fed into the High Temp Pump Package (HTPR).  The Low Temp Pump Package (LTPR) is then fed liquid from the High Temp Pump Receiver (HTPR).

Secondary Ammonia Cycles
	High Pressure Liquid (HPL) ammonia is directed from the High Pressure Receiver (HPR) to the compressors and is injected into the compressor for oil cooling.
